close_symbols: (all) buffer-size macros and filesystem structure definitions referenced by OS_FileSys_Initialize and its _Impl functions (e.g. max device name length, max volume name length, internal destination buffer sizes)
explanation:
- OS_FileSys_Initialize: the target forwards its string pointers (address, devname, volname) into this function. You must inspect its implementation to see whether it calls any <string.h> functions (memcpy/strcpy/strncpy/strlen/etc.) on those pointers and how it computes destination sizes.  
- OS_FileSysFormatVolume_Impl, OS_FileSysStartVolume_Impl, OS_FileSysStopVolume_Impl: these implementation helpers (called by OS_FileSys_Initialize per the call graph) are the most likely places that perform formatting/copying of the provided strings or operate on internal buffers; they must be examined for use of string.h APIs and for correct bounds checks.  
- OS_printf: logging calls can trigger formatting operations; while not strictly a <string.h> function, they may reveal how strings are constructed/validated and whether any intermediate string operations are used (e.g., via vsnprintf) — include for completeness when tracing string handling.  
- OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken, OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew: object-id/name management helpers sometimes copy/validate names or index into name tables; if OS_FileSys_Initialize delegates name handling to these, they need to be checked for string.h usage and bounds handling.  
- osal_blockcount_t, int32, size_t: the types are needed to understand sizes/limits used in copying/allocations and to reason about buffer length computations.  
- OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE, OS_ERR_NO_FREE_IDS, OS_FS_ERR_DEVICE_NOT_FREE: the error constants are required to understand control-flow (early returns) so you know which code paths that perform string operations actually execute.  
- (all) buffer-size macros and filesystem structure definitions referenced by OS_FileSys_Initialize and its _Impl functions (e.g. maximum device name length, maximum volume name length, internal destination buffer sizes): these are essential to determine destination buffer capacities and therefore to decide whether any use of memcpy/strcpy/etc. can access beyond the bounds of the referenced objects.  

In short: start with OS_FileSys_Initialize and recursively inspect its callees and any buffer-size/structure definitions they reference; those symbols provide the information needed to determine whether any <string.h> use can overflow destination buffers or read past source bounds.
